question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 1 In adults, where is the inferior border of the spinal cord?
options: Intervertebral disc between L1 and L2
answerText: Intervertebral disc between L1 and L2
explanation: In adults, the spinal cord typically ends at the level of the L1-L2 intervertebral disc.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 2 Which one is located in the inferior one-third of the vertebral canal?
explanation: The filum terminale extends from the conus medullaris and anchors the spinal cord to the sacrum.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 3 Which tract has crossing and is located in the anterior funiculus of the spinal cord?
explanation: The tectospinal tract originates from the superior colliculus, crosses, and descends in the anterior funiculus.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 4 Which tract doesn’t have any crossing and is located in the lateral funiculus of the spinal cord?
explanation: The posterior spinocerebellar tract remains uncrossed and carries proprioceptive information to the cerebellum.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 5 Which spinal nerve emerges between the atlas and axis?
explanation: The C2 spinal nerve exits between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2).

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 6 In a fracture of the vertebral column at the level of T8, which spinal cord segment is damaged?
explanation: The spinal cord segments are higher than their corresponding vertebrae, with T11 corresponding to T8.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 7 Where is the location of the pyramidal decussation?
options: Inferior compartment of the closed part of the medulla oblongata
answerText: Inferior compartment of the closed part of the medulla oblongata
explanation: The pyramidal decussation occurs in the lower medulla, where corticospinal fibers cross.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 8 Which one is the parasympathetic nucleus of the vagus nerve?
explanation: The dorsal nucleus of the vagus nerve provides parasympathetic output to thoracic and abdominal organs.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 9 Which fibers of the facial nerve turn around the abducens nucleus and form the facial colliculus?
explanation: The motor fibers of the facial nerve loop around the abducens nucleus in the pons, forming the facial colliculus.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 10 Which one is located in the basilar part of the pons?
explanation: The basilar part of the pons contains pontine nuclei, which relay information from the cortex to the cerebellum.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 11 Which one is related to the visual system?
explanation: The superior colliculus is involved in visual reflexes and tracking movements of the eyes.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 12 In the substantia nigra pars compacta, which one is a byproduct of dopamine?
explanation: Neuromelanin is a byproduct of dopamine metabolism and gives the substantia nigra its dark color.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 13 Which nucleus is located in the superior part of the midbrain and extends into the subthalamic area?
explanation: The red nucleus is involved in motor coordination and extends into the subthalamic region.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 14 Which one is on the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle?
explanation: The tail of the caudate nucleus curves around and forms part of the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 15 Which one is between the external capsule and extreme capsule?
explanation: The claustrum is a thin gray matter structure located between the external and extreme capsules.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 16 Where is the location of Bergmann’s cells?
options: Molecular layer of the cerebral cortex
Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex
answerText: Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex
explanation: Bergmann’s cells are specialized astrocytes found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellar cortex.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 17 Which one is related to the paleocerebellum?
explanation: The emboliform nucleus is part of the paleocerebellum (spinocerebellum) and is involved in motor coordination.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 18 In the cerebellar cortex, which neurons are excitatory?
explanation: Granule cells in the cerebellar cortex are the only excitatory neurons, releasing glutamate.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 19 Which part of the brain doesn’t have neurons and a blood-brain barrier?
explanation: The pineal body lacks a blood-brain barrier to allow hormone secretion directly into circulation.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 20 The superior surface of the hippocampus is covered by:
explanation: The alveus is a thin layer of white matter covering the hippocampus, forming part of the fornix pathway.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 21 Rostrum, genu, body, and splenium are parts of the ….
explanation: The corpus callosum is the largest commissural fiber bundle in the brain, connecting the two hemispheres.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 22 The anterior inferior cerebellar artery is a branch of the ….
explanation: The anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) arises from the basilar artery and supplies the cerebellum.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 23 Broca’s motor speech area is supplied by:
explanation: The middle cerebral artery supplies Broca’s area in the dominant hemisphere, responsible for speech production.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 24 Which one is avascular and without innervation?
explanation: The arachnoid mater lacks blood vessels and nerve supply, forming a protective layer between dura and pia mater.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 25 The paracentral lobule is supplied by:
explanation: The anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule, which controls lower limb motor and sensory functions.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 26 Which part of the basal nuclei has glutamatergic neurons?
explanation: The subthalamic nucleus is the only excitatory (glutamatergic) component of the basal ganglia circuitry.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 27 Which one is responsible for pupil constriction?
explanation: The pretectal nucleus is involved in the pupillary light reflex, signaling the Edinger-Westphal nucleus for constriction.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 28 The labyrinthine artery is a branch of the …. artery
explanation: The labyrinthine artery (internal auditory artery) arises from the basilar artery and supplies the inner ear.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 29 Where is the location of the hippocampus?
options: Floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle
answerText: Floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle
explanation: The hippocampus lies in the medial temporal lobe and forms the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 30 Where is the location of the primary visual area?
explanation: The primary visual cortex (V1) is located in the cuneus and lingual gyrus along the calcarine sulcus.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 31 Which one is medial to the rhinal sulcus?
explanation: The parahippocampal gyrus is located medial to the rhinal sulcus and is involved in memory processing.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 32 Which thalamic nuclei participate in the Papez circuit?
options: Dorsal tier of the lateral group
explanation: The anterior thalamic nuclei relay information within the Papez circuit, which is essential for memory and emotions.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 33 Which hypothalamic nucleus is located in the interpeduncular fossa?
explanation: The mammillary bodies are part of the hypothalamus and play a role in memory circuits.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 34 Which neurons are located in the molecular layer of the cerebral cortex?
explanation: Cajal-Retzius cells in the molecular layer guide neuronal migration during cortical development.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 35 Which one is lateral to the diencephalon?
explanation: The internal capsule is a white matter structure that lies lateral to the diencephalon and contains major projection fibers.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 36 Which one is between the apex of the posterior gray column and the posterolateral sulcus of the spinal cord?
explanation: Lissauer’s tract contains sensory fibers for pain and temperature, running between the dorsal horn and the posterolateral sulcus.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 37 Which tract has two crossings?
explanation: The anterior spinocerebellar tract crosses twice, first in the spinal cord and then in the cerebellum.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 38 The medial lemniscus is formed by:
explanation: The medial lemniscus is formed by decussating internal arcuate fibers from the dorsal column nuclei.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 39 Where is the emerging site of the accessory nerve?
options: Posterolateral sulcus of the medulla oblongata
answerText: Posterolateral sulcus of the medulla oblongata
explanation: The spinal accessory nerve emerges from the posterolateral sulcus of the medulla and spinal cord.

question: First Batch (2024-02-13) - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 40 Which one is between the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli?
explanation: The straight sinus is located where the falx cerebri meets the tentorium cerebelli and drains blood from deep brain structures.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 1 Where is location of the cauda equina?
options: Middle one third of vertebral canal
Lower one third of vertebral canal
answerText: Lower one third of vertebral canal
explanation: The cauda equina is located in the lower one third of the vertebral canal.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 2 All of the following structures are related to hearing, EXCEPT:
explanation: The lateral geniculate body is part of the visual pathway, not the auditory system.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 3 Which thalamic nuclei are related to motor coordination?
explanation: The ventral anterior and ventral lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in motor coordination.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 4 Which cranial nerve emerges from the medial border of the cerebral peduncle?
explanation: The oculomotor nerve emerges from the medial border of the cerebral peduncle.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 5 Which nucleus has dopaminergic neurons?
explanation: Dopaminergic neurons are primarily found in the substantia nigra pars compacta.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 6 All of the following regions are related to the pathway of corticospinal tract, EXCEPT:
options: Posterior limb of the internal capsule
Anterior limb of the internal capsule
answerText: Anterior limb of the internal capsule
explanation: The corticospinal tract does not pass through the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 7 Which nucleus is between the internal and external capsules?
explanation: The lentiform nucleus is located between the internal and external capsules.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 8 Which one is in the medial surface of the occipital lobe?
explanation: The cuneus is a wedge-shaped area located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 9 Where is the location of the motor speech area?
explanation: The motor speech area (Broca’s area) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 10 Which one is afferents of anterior thalamic nuclei?
explanation: The anterior thalamic nuclei receive afferents from the mammillothalamic tract.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 11 All of the following structures are related to archicerebellum, EXCEPT:
explanation: The tonsils are part of the posterior lobe of the cerebellum, not the archicerebellum.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 12 Motor and sensory parts of cortex for lower limb are supplied by which artery?
explanation: The anterior cerebral artery supplies the medial part of the cerebral hemisphere, including the motor and sensory cortices for the lower limb.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 13 Which neuron has a soma in the deep layers of the cerebral cortex and axon terminals in the molecular layer?
explanation: Martinotti cells have their soma in the deep layers of the cortex and send their axons to the molecular layer.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 14 Which tract is located in the posterior funiculus of the spinal cord?
explanation: The fasciculus cuneatus is part of the dorsal column pathway, located in the posterior funiculus.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 15 All of the following nuclei are related to the vagus nerve, EXCEPT:
options: Spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve
explanation: The inferior salivatory nucleus is related to the glossopharyngeal nerve, not the vagus nerve.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 16 Which structure is located in the interpeduncular fossa?
explanation: The posterior perforated substance is located in the interpeduncular fossa.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 17 Which part of the brain lacks neurons and blood-brain barrier?
explanation: The pineal body lacks a blood-brain barrier and is involved in hormone secretion.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 18 Which nucleus is the parasympathetic nucleus of the oculomotor nerve?
explanation: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus is the parasympathetic nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, controlling pupillary constriction.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 19 Where is the location of the Emboliform nucleus?
explanation: The emboliform nucleus is located in the paleocerebellum, part of the cerebellar deep nuclei.

question: First Batch (2024-10-07) Retake Exam - Dr. Hasanzadeh - Question 20 Which sulcus is located in the medial surface of the occipital lobe?
explanation: The calcarine sulcus is located on the medial surface of the occipital lobe and is associated with the primary visual cortex.
